habitat_description:
Dipodomys agilis primarily inhabits areas of coastal sage scrub (Vaughn, 1954; M’Closkey, 1976; Price and Waser, 1984; Goldingjay and Price, 1997), but is also found in chaparral (Vaughn, 1954; Lackey, 1967), interior sagebrush (Vaughn, 1954), and greasewood (Vaughn, 1954). The species prefers more open shrub cover (26-50%; Meserve, 1976), with ample bare ground and sand (Vauhgn, 1954; M’Closkey, 1976; Meserve, 1976; Goldingjay and Price, 1997). While grass cover is often up to 50% in the species’ habitats (Lackey, 1967; Price et al., 1991), D. agilis is rare in grasslands devoid of shrubs (Lackey, 1967; Price et al., 1991; Goldingjay and Price, 1997). Those reported in grasslands have all been within 45 m of sage scrub (Price et al., 1991). They are completely absent from wooded areas (Vaughn, 1954). The species’ abundance increases after fire (Price and Waser, 1984).

Individuals have been documented at elevations up to 2253 m (Vaughn, 1954).
